"SECTION 1. FINDINGS."

Summarized: Section 1 presents the findings. "Congress finds that Jackie Roosevelt Robinson, born in 1919 in Cairo, Georgia, excelled in multiple sports at UCLA before becoming the first black player in Major League Baseball in 1947. He was awarded the National League's Rookie of the Year in his first season and voted the Most Valuable Player in 1949." Jackie Robinson's achievements extended beyond athletics, influencing civil and human rights in America. He was the first black player in Major League Baseball, winning the National League's Rookie of the Year in 1947 and being voted the Most Valuable Player in 1949. In 1962, he was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame. His signing preceded significant events in desegregation and civil rights history in the United States. Jackie Robinson's influence extended beyond athletics, as he was regarded as a person of exceptional fortitude and integrity. He was named vice president of Chock Full O' Nuts in 1957 and co-founded the Freedom National Bank of Harlem. Robinson's leadership influenced many political leaders in America. Jackie Robinson's legacy extends beyond athletics, as he was named vice president of Chock Full O' Nuts in 1957 and co-founded the Freedom National Bank of Harlem. He worked with various organizations to improve the lives of Americans and his principles are upheld by the Jackie Robinson Foundation, providing educational opportunities for children from low-income families. Robinson's personal achievements have had a lasting positive impact on civil rights in the United States. The President is authorized to present a gold medal to Jackie Robinson's family in recognition of his contributions to the nation. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. Duplicates in bronze may be sold to cover costs. The medals struck under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code. An amount not to exceed $30,000 is authorized to pay for the cost of the medal, with proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. Congress suggests designating a national day to recognize Jackie Robinson's accomplishments, with the President issuing a proclamation for observance. The Senate passed S. 300 on October 17, 2003, awarding a congressional gold medal to Jackie Robinson posthumously for his contributions to the nation. Congress also suggests establishing a national day in recognition of Jackie Robinson.
